newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Justice ministers agree steps to fight child sex trade.
newsitem.headline: Justice ministers agree steps to fight child sex trade.

text.p: European Union justice ministers, reacting to a Belgian child-murder and sex scandal, agreed on Thursday to extend the scope of the EU's police agency Europol so it could help fight the sex trade in children and women.

A spokesman for the Irish EU presidency said the ministers, meeting for a two-day session in Dublin, reached political agreement on an Irish plan to extend the mandate of the Europol Drugs Unit to cover such crimes.

"We intend to fight against the work of criminals in the trafficking of people in the same way as we fight against drugs trafficking," the chief of the Europol drugs unit, Juergen Storbeck, told reporters.

The agreement, which also includes a move to promote the exchange of police officers throughout the EU and set up centres of excellence in fighting this form of crime will be formalised at a future meeting of EU ministers.
The 15-nation EU has been stung into action after the discovery of the bodies of four murdered girls in Belgium highlighted the international trade in child sex and pornography.

Storbeck said the Hague-based agency would help exchange information between different police bureaus in the EU, identify problems in international cooperation and develop new methods of fighting the crime.

But Storbeck urged the ministers to act urgently to ratify the Europol convention, as only once it is ratified will the agency be able what it does best -- pooling and analysing information via its central computer. 261238 GMT sep 96
